item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation 🔗

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle and other animals under unusual and anomalous circumstances, often characterized by bloodless excisions. The phenomenon is frequently associated with paranormal and supernatural explanations, though conventional explanations also exist.

Early History 🔗

The earliest documented cases of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 🔗

In 1967, the death of a horse named “Snippy” in Alamosa, Colorado, gained national attention. The horse was found mutilated with precise cuts and no blood at the scene. This case was the first to link mutilations to extraterrestrial beings and UFOs. Wadsworth Ayer’s investigation for the Condon Committee concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Alamosa County Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike, but later reports mentioned the horse had been shot. Two students confessed to shooting the horse after the case was publicized.

Cattle Mutilations 1973–1980 🔗

This section covers a period of increased reports of cattle mutilations in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico. In April 1973, sheriffs in Western Iowa reported unidentified helicopters involved in cattle and pig rustling. Similar rustling was reported in Missouri in August.

1973 Kansas Wave 🔗

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about a caller posing as a USDA official. A series of butchered cows were found on farms in Cloud County, Kansas, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a ‘Mad Dog’ or ‘phantom’ Butcher. By December, law enforcement reported 40 mutilations across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, but Modlin disagreed.

1974 Nebraska Wave 🔗

Reports resumed in April 1974 with a mutilated cow in Nebraska drained of blood. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. Mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, and Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer Country reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. An unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By August, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when he found a helicopter above his field. Authorities cautioned the public not to shoot at aircraft. The University of Nebraska’s Department of Veterinary Science disproved three mutilations as natural deaths. Law enforcement officials from 24 counties attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, to discuss the mutilations. Three cases of alleged mutilations were reported in South Dakota. Newsweek covered the story, reporting 100 cattle mutilated in Nebraska, Kansas, and Iowa since May. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande reported mutilations in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Two mutilations were reported in Kandiyohi County, six in Swift County, and one in Meeker County, Minnesota.

1975 Colorado 🔗

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report indicated an estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing approximately $1 million in damages. The Michigan ATF tasked Donald E. Flickinger with investigating the mutilations. The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico 🔗

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting 🔗

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. Valdez reported two drugs found in a mutilated bull’s remains, suggesting a sophisticated operation. On June 14, 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents 🔗

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002.

In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated male human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of São Paulo, Brazil, in 1988. Theories ranged from homicide to alien abduction.

Characteristics 🔗

Cattle deaths due to natural causes are common. Ranchers reported unusual cattle deaths characterized by absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts were described as “clean” and “surgical”. Some animals were reported to have been drained of blood. Howard Burgess stated that nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found. In the “Snippy” case, there was an absence of tracks and small holes were found seemingly “punched” in the ground. In Rio Arriba County, New Mexico, a “trail of suction cup-like impressions” was found leading from a mutilated cow.

Laboratory Reports 🔗

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In one case in Dulce, New Mexico, an 11-month-old bull was found mutilated with classic signs. The animal’s heart and liver were found to be inconsistent with a normal case of death followed by predation. Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory detected Clostridium bacteria in the heart. Samples from the animal’s liver were found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain 4 times the normal level of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were reported to be “light pink in color” and “Did not clot after several days”.

Helicopter Sightings 🔗

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters were reported to have opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported that residents had seen unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. Authorities ran ads urging ranchers not to shoot at survey helicopters. The National Guard warned its helicopter pilots to fly at higher than normal altitude. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted several men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilation.

Official Investigations 🔗

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms 🔗

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger. Flickinger was tasked with investigating the possible connections between cults and the mutilation of cattle. He recorded unusual incidents and circumstantial evidence but was unable to find sufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation 🔗

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under the leadership of Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University but no conclusive results emerged. The US Bureau of Land Management was forced to ground all helicopters in Eastern Colorado. By December, the CBI had investigated 203 reports of cattle mutilations. The CBI investigation was closed after Colorado mutiliation reports dwindled in Summer 1976.

New Mexico State Police 🔗

On June 13, 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation, headed by Officer Gabe Valdez with the assistance of Cattle Inspector Jim Dyad and Officer Howard Johnston of the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish. Valdez solicited the assistance of retired Sandia National Laboratories scientist Howard Burgess. On the night of July 5, suspecting that cattle might be “marked” in a way detectable from the air at night, Burgess and Valdez screened the Gomez herd; five animals were found to have been marked with a chemical that fluoresced under ultraviolet light. On June 14, 1981, intact radar chaff was found near a mutilated cow on the Gomez ranch. item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials 🔗

In ufology, “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites” are terms for humanoid races from the Pleiades star cluster (Pleiadians) who resemble Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans. Contactees describe them as taller than average humans (6-7 ft), with “European” features like blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin, sometimes with pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones.

In the 1950s, George Adamski claimed contact with Nordics. These beings are often portrayed as telepathic, benevolent, beautiful, and graceful. Telepathy is often the primary communication method in alien encounters.

History 🔗

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early Nordic alien stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” with Nordic aliens associated with spiritual growth and protection.

Nordic aliens are often depicted as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

Claims of encounters with Nordic aliens were common in Europe during the 1950s but became less frequent as the grey alien became more prominent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted 🔗

Several books detail alleged personal contact with Nordic aliens, including:

  • George Adamski’s Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships
  • Howard Menger’s From Outer Space to You
  • Travis Walton’s The Walton Experience
  • Charles James Hall’s Millennial Hospitality (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People publishes “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends” detailing interactions with cosmic beings.

See also 🔗

This section lists related topics, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from another world rather than Earth. While no extraterrestrial life has been conclusively detected, the possibility ranges from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The science dedicated to studying extraterrestrial life is astrobiology.

Context 🔗

This section provides a framework for understanding the topic of life in the universe. It lists various celestial bodies within and outside the Solar System that are considered potentially habitable, including Venus, Mars, Europa, Enceladus, and Titan. It also touches on the conditions necessary for life, such as the presence of liquid water and a suitable atmosphere. The section explains that the universe was initially too hot for life after the Big Bang and that the necessary elements for life, like carbon and oxygen, were formed later through stellar fusion. It also introduces the concepts of abiogenesis and panspermia as potential origins and spread of life.

Likelihood of Existence 🔗

This section explores the debate on whether extraterrestrial life is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous life, emphasizing the size and age of the universe, the ubiquity of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws. Key figures like Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view, along with the Copernican and mediocrity principles. The opposing Rare Earth hypothesis is also discussed, which suggests that life on Earth is due to a unique combination of factors unlikely to be replicated elsewhere. The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way. The Fermi paradox, the apparent contradiction between the high probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for them, is also mentioned.

Biochemical Basis 🔗

This section delves into the potential biochemical characteristics of extraterrestrial life. It discusses the basic requirements for life, such as non-equilibrium thermodynamics and a source of energy, mentioning stars, volcanoes, plate tectonics, and hydrothermal vents as possible energy sources. The importance of water as a solvent is highlighted, along with alternative solvents like ammonia and hydrocarbons. The section also explores the possibility of different chemical elements forming the basis of life, considering elements like boron, nitrogen, phosphorus, and silicon as potential alternatives to carbon. The section also discusses the likelihood of cell membranes and evolution being universal characteristics of life, even if the specific biochemistry differs from that on Earth. Simon Conway Morris’s ideas on convergent evolution leading to similar lifeforms as on Earth are also mentioned.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life 🔗

This section highlights that while conditions on other planets may seem too extreme to harbor life, some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments. Fossil evidence and theories suggest that hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs could have been the origin of life on Earth. These environments support chemosynthetic processes, allowing organisms to utilize energy through reduced chemical compounds that fix carbon. The early Earth environment was reducing, and these carbon-fixing compounds were necessary for survival and the possible origin of life. The atmospheres on other planets are most likely reducing or with very low oxygen levels, especially when compared with Earth’s atmosphere. If there were the necessary elements and ions on these planets, the same carbon-fixing, reduced chemical compounds occurring around hydrothermal vents could also occur on these planets’ surfaces and possibly result in the origin of extraterrestrial life.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System 🔗

This section assesses the potential for life on various bodies within the Solar System. Besides Earth, Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. Mars is described as a cold desert, but with evidence of past abundant water. The gas giants are considered unlikely to harbor life, but their moons, particularly Europa and Enceladus, are of interest due to their subsurface oceans. Titan, with its liquid hydrocarbon bodies, is also mentioned as a unique case.

Scientific Search 🔗

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology, the science dedicated to this search, combines various disciplines like astronomy, biology, chemistry, and geology. The search is carried out both directly, by looking for biosignatures within the Solar System and examining meteorites, and indirectly, by searching for exoplanets that may be conducive to life. The section mentions the discovery of thousands of exoplanets and the ongoing efforts to assess their habitability.

Search for Basic Life 🔗

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures, indicators of life, on other planets. It mentions claims of evidence for microbial life on Mars, including structures resembling nanobacteria in the ALH84001 meteorite and gas emissions from Martian soil samples. The Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover are mentioned as ongoing efforts to assess past and present habitability on Mars. The section also discusses the discovery of organic molecules, such as adenine and guanine, in meteorites found on Antarctica, suggesting that the building blocks of life may be generated within asteroids and comets. The detection of glycolaldehyde, a sugar molecule needed to form RNA, in a distant star system is also mentioned. The discovery of hydrogen cyanide in the plumes of Enceladus is also discussed.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences 🔗

This section shifts the focus to the search for intelligent extraterrestrial life. It discusses the concept of technosignatures, effects on a planet that may indicate the presence of technology. The SETI Institute’s search for radio waves and laser pulses is mentioned, along with the challenges of distinguishing artificial signals from natural sources. The section also explores potential atmospheric technosignatures, such as nitrogen dioxide and chlorofluorocarbons, and the possibility of detecting planetary-sized structures like Dyson spheres.

Extrasolar Planets 🔗

This section details the search for exoplanets, particularly terrestrial planets within the habitable zones of their stars. It mentions the discovery of thousands of exoplanets and the Kepler space telescope’s role in detecting candidate planets. The section highlights the estimate that at least one in five Sun-like stars has an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone, suggesting the potential for billions of habitable planets in the Milky Way. Proxima Centauri b, the nearest known exoplanet, is also mentioned.

History and Cultural Impact 🔗

This section traces the historical development of ideas about extraterrestrial life and its cultural influence.

Cosmic Pluralism 🔗

This section discusses the philosophical belief in numerous worlds beyond Earth that might harbor life. It mentions early thinkers like Anaximander, Epicurus, and Aristotle, and their differing views on the nature of the cosmos and the possibility of other worlds. Medieval Muslim writers and Chaucer are also mentioned as contributors to the idea of cosmic pluralism.

Early Modern Period 🔗

This section covers the period of the Copernican Revolution and its impact on the concept of extraterrestrial life. It mentions Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo Galilei as key figures in the shift from a geocentric to a heliocentric model of the universe. Giordano Bruno’s advocacy for an infinite universe with numerous planetary systems is also discussed, along with his persecution for these beliefs. The section also mentions Isaac Newton’s theory of gravity as further solidifying the heliocentric model.

19th Century 🔗

This section focuses on the 19th century, highlighting the increased speculation about life on Mars following telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell’s books proposing that the canals were the work of a long-gone civilization are mentioned. The section also discusses spectroscopic analysis of Mars’s atmosphere, which revealed the absence of water and oxygen. Louis Pasteur’s disproving of spontaneous generation is mentioned, along with the rise of the science fiction genre and its influence on public perception of extraterrestrial life.

Recent History 🔗

This section covers the modern era, with the emergence of astrobiology as a scientific discipline. It mentions NASA, ESA, and INAF as organizations involved in astrobiology research. The section also discusses the rise of pseudosciences like ufology and the ancient astronauts hypothesis. It also mentions the Rare Earth hypothesis, which claims that Earth-like life is rare in the universe. Stephen Hawking’s warning about the potential dangers of contacting alien life forms is also mentioned, along with the Breakthrough Initiatives, a well-funded effort to expand the search for extraterrestrial life.

Government Responses 🔗

This section outlines the governmental and international policies related to extraterrestrial life. The 1967 Outer Space Treaty and the 1979 Moon Agreement are mentioned as defining rules of planetary protection against potentially hazardous extraterrestrial life. COSPAR’s guidelines for planetary protection are also noted. The section also mentions the lack of UN response mechanisms for the case of an extraterrestrial contact. The roles of NASA’s Planetary Protection Office, the Chinese space program, the Russian space agency, and the French space agency in studying and searching for extraterrestrial life are also discussed.

In Fiction 🔗

This section explores the portrayal of extraterrestrial life in fiction. It discusses how the theory of evolution influenced science fiction authors to create bizarre aliens distinct from humans. The limitations of costuming and special effects in early films and TV series are mentioned, along with the impact of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more realistic aliens. The Barney and Betty Hill incident and its influence on the grey alien archetype are also discussed.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts 🔗

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected modern cultures, technologies, religions, and human biology. A common idea is that deities from religions are extraterrestrial in origin, with advanced technologies interpreted as divine status by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeological or unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed studies. Some argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist undertones, diminishing the accomplishments of indigenous cultures.

Overview 🔗

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers maintain that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence who landed on Earth in the past. They propose that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island or aided humans in their construction. Evidence is drawn from documentary gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as archaeological artifacts considered anachronistic.

As a pseudoarcheology, the idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to spread theories of an alternate past with tropes that follow white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents focus on monumental archaeological structures, implying that non-white Indigenous people could not have built them on their own. However, some indigenous peoples believe the denial of extraterrestrial encounters and indigenous peoples’ stories tracing their origins to extraterrestrials is part of “Indigenous erasure,” as it minimizes or completely discounts the viewpoints of indigenous peoples.

A common feature in the stories portray the aliens as light-skinned or Aryan in complexion, as prominent alien astronaut proponent Erich von Däniken claims in his foundational work Chariots of the Gods? Some ancient astronaut proponents are thus associated with white supremacism, although their theories are sometimes applied to European cultures as well.

Mainstream archaeologists largely ignored these claims until recently, while popular science explainers and skeptics universally panned them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of apparent interest have reasonable alternative explanations, misreporting, prevarications, hoaxes, and distortions.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents 🔗

Paleocontact narratives first appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Journalist Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It grew in popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von Däniken’s works, but critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von Däniken’s claims. Ufologists separated the idea from the UFO controversy, and by the early 1980s, little support remained.

Shklovskii and Sagan 🔗

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan expressed disapproval of “von Däniken and other uncritical writers” who built on these ideas as valid evidence of extraterrestrial contact. Sagan pointed out that many legends, artifacts, and purported out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be easily explained with more conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits to Earth were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von Däniken 🔗

Erich von Däniken was a leading proponent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis in the late 1960s and early 1970s, gaining a large audience through his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels. Von Däniken argues that certain artifacts required more sophisticated technology than was available to ancient cultures, suggesting they were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. These include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

Von Däniken writes that ancient art and iconography illustrate air and space vehicles, non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He also states that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. He interprets the sarcophagus lid of Maya ruler Pacal the Great as a seated astronaut, while the iconography identifies it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree of Maya mythology.

Von Däniken interprets the origins of religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, viewing their technology as supernatural and the aliens as gods. He states that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors, such as Ezekiel’s revelation, which he interprets as a landing spacecraft.

Critics argue that von Däniken misrepresented data, made unfounded claims, and that none of his core claims have been validated. Christian creationists are critical of his work, with Clifford A. Wilson publishing Crash Go the Chariots (1972) to discredit Chariots of the Gods.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von Däniken states that they appeared to him as an airfield when seen from the air. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate them with extraterrestrial origins. In 1970, von Däniken admitted that the Nazca markings could have been laid out using a system of coordinates.

Zecharia Sitchin 🔗

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesizes that the gods of Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru orbits the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support Sitchin’s ideas.

Sitchin argues that Sumerian texts tell the story of 50 Anunnaki from Nibiru who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers to work the mines, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the end of the last ice age.

Sitchin’s work has not received mainstream scholarly support and has been criticized by professionals. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are not consistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform bilingual dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium (1996), was an adherent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis but now finds fault with Sitchin’s hypothesis, stating that the gods personified the falling sky.

Robert Temple 🔗

Robert K. G. Temple’s The Sirius Mystery (1976) argues that the Dogon people of Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He quotes evidence including advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies and suggest that the Dogon may have received their astronomical information recently from European sources and may have misrepresented Dogon ethnography.

UFO Religions 🔗

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, Raëlism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many of these faiths see both ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens from other planetary systems. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities which suggest that members consciously or subliminally associate enchantment with science fiction memes.

Claims of Proponents 🔗

The consensus among scientists is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts; proponents look for mysteries where none exist. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts 🔗

Proponents cite ancient mythologies to support their viewpoints, based on the idea that ancient creation myths of gods descending from the heavens to Earth to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors, whose superior technology accounts for their perception as gods. They draw an analogy to modern occurrences when isolated cultures are exposed to advanced technology, such as cargo cults in the South Pacific.

The ancient Sumerian myth of Enûma Eliš, inscribed on cuneiform tablets, says humankind was created to serve gods called the “Annunaki.” Hypothesis proponents believe that the Annunaki were aliens who came to Earth to mine gold for their own uses and then created the human race as slaves.

Ramayana 🔗

In Hindu mythology, the gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana.

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) 🔗

This entry focuses on the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background 🔗

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, starting with the events of 1947.

Events of 1947 🔗

This subsection details the initial reports surrounding the Roswell incident. It mentions the flying disc craze of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, and the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed object, which was quickly retracted and explained as a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited 🔗

This subsection highlights the renewed interest in the Roswell story in 1978, sparked by an interview with retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel, who claimed the debris he retrieved was of extraterrestrial origin. Stanton Friedman, a ufologist, conducted the interview.

Authors 🔗

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. Berlitz is noted for authoring The Bermuda Triangle, a best-selling book that popularized the Bermuda Triangle mystery. Berlitz and Moore also collaborated on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility, which popularized the tale of a Navy invisibility experiment.

Contents 🔗

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It mentions accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” by Jesse Marcel. Other individuals mentioned include Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The book is described as “version 1” of the Roswell myth. It also introduces the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of a cover-up and that the press was not allowed to closely inspect the recovered material. The authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of their testimonies appear in the book. The incarceration of Mac Brazel is also mentioned. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative over that of Cavitt.

Alien bodies 🔗

This section discusses the book’s introduction of stories about alien bodies. It mentions the second-hand accounts of Grady “Barney” Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also notes that some accounts of the Roswell incident contain information from the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoax promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception 🔗

This section notes that critics deemed The Roswell Incident as “a collection of wild hearsay” and that the Majestic 12 documents were considered fraudulent. It also mentions that the book “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.”

Aftermath 🔗

This section mentions that William Moore claimed to have engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views 🔗

This section references a 1993 inquiry from US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a General Accounting Office investigation and an Air Force report. The 1994 Air Force report concluded that the material recovered in 1947 was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)
